content.description: Soluble reactive phosphate (<math alttext="S R P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SRP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>) is a term used to describe the amount of phosphate available for uptake by living things. A study of river plants species and water phosphate levels was completed in Great Britain. Recently, in a section of one of the rivers studied, a population of fennel-leaved pondweed was replaced by spiked water-milfoil, even though these two plants are associated with different environmental conditions as indicated in the table below.
content.question: Table 1. Concentrations of phosphate and river plant correlations in Britain <math alttext="S R P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SRP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Concentration <math alttext="in milligrams per liter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>mg/</mtext><mtext>L</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> Plant Species Observed <math alttext="less than 0.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo><</mo><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Bog pondweed (Potamogeton polygonifolius) and river water-crowfoot (Ranunculus fluitans) <math alttext="0.1 minus 0.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>4</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Fennel-leaved pondweed (Potamogeton pectinatus) <math alttext="0.4 minus 1.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mtext>.4</mtext><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mn>1</mn><mtext>.</mtext><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> Yellow water-lily (Nuphar lutea) and arrowhead (Sagittarias agittifolia) <math alttext="greater than 1.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>></mo><mn>1</mn><mtext>.0</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Spiked water-milfoil (Myriophyllum spicatum) A group of researchers suggest that the concentration of available phosphate in this particular section of the British river does not have a significant impact on which plant species grow. Alternatively, another group of researchers hypothesize that levels of available phosphate do affect which plant species grow at this location. Which of the following observations would best support this alternative hypothesis?

choices.label: Reforestation efforts in Britain near this section of the river have caused changes in the plant community structure.
Increased fertilizer use near this section of the river has led to increased runoff of phosphates into the river.
Spiked water-milfoil adapted to lower phosphorous conditions has been observed to outcompete fennel-leaved pondweed in this section of the river.

Measured levels of <math alttext="S R P" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>SRP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in this section of the river have remained constant over a period of time.

content.answer: Increased fertilizer use near this section of the river has led to increased runoff of phosphates into the river.

skill.text: 5.D: Use data to evaluate a hypothesis or prediction, including rejecting or failing to reject the null hypothesis.
